cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who led the soldiers in ending the raid on the harper's ferry arsenal
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: The raid on Harper's Ferry was led by John Brown, an abolitionist who aimed to initiate an armed slave revolt by capturing the United States arsenal at Harper's Ferry, Virginia (now West Virginia). The raid took place in October 1859. Brown and his followers were ultimately confronted by U.S. Marines, led by Colonel Robert E. Lee, who were sent to suppress the raid. Therefore, while John Brown led the initial raid, it was Colonel Lee who led the soldiers in ending it.

Answer: Colonel Robert E. Lee led the soldiers in ending the raid on the Harper's Ferry arsenal.

['Elements of the 2nd Armored Division began to arrive in Algeria, French North Africa, in November 1942, as part of Operation Torch. Upon landing in Algiers, Harmon was delegated by General Dwight D. "Ike" Eisenhower, the Supreme Allied Commander in North Africa, to travel to the front to report on the deteriorating Allied situation in Tunisia and Algeria, and to assist where needed. His on-site reporting and interventions during the Kasserine Pass battles in February 1943 helped stabilize and reorganize the U.S. II Corps, which had been thrown into disorder after the initial German attack.\n', 'In November 1941, these men carried out a raid on Beda Littoria, in Libya as part of Operation Flipper, with the purpose of capturing Erwin Rommel in his headquarters. The raid was a failure, Keyes was killed in a fire fight at Sidi Rafa and only a handful of the men managed to escape to British lines. For his part in the raid, Keyes received the Victoria Cross posthumously. After this raid the commando role changed and No. 11 Commando along with Layforce was disbanded, due mainly to a shortage of manpower.\n', 'In April 1941, the Royal Navy and the RAF devised Operation Fuller, a plan for combined operations against the ships in Brest should they sortie. Vice-Admiral Bertram Ramsay of the Dover Command was to be responsible for operations to confront a German squadron sailing up the Channel with continuous co-ordinated attacks by Coastal Command, the Navy and RAF. The British coastal radar had a range of about and with the five standing air patrols, the planners expected a dash up the Channel easily to be discovered, even at night or in bad weather. As soon as the alarm was raised, the offensive provisions of Fuller would begin as a combined operation. The of the Dover and Ramsgate flotillas, with a Motor Gun Boat (MGB) escort, would make torpedo attacks from . The boats would be followed up by Swordfish torpedo-bombers with fighter escorts and Beaufort torpedo-bombers and the coastal guns at Dover would fire for as long as the ships were in range; Bomber Command would attack any ship damaged enough to have been slowed or brought to a stop.\n', 'In June, the Royal Navy undertook Operation Harpoon and Operation Vigorous. The two convoys departed for Malta, the former from Gibraltar, the latter from Haifa and Port Said. The move was designed to split Axis naval forces attempting to intervene. Lloyd the AOC, wanted to give No. 601 Squadron over to convoy escort duty. Although he could afford this diversion, he could maintain a standing patrol of only four Spitfires over the convoy. If Axis aircraft attacked as they were withdrawing, they had to stay and fight. Bailing out if the pilots ran low on fuel was the only alternative to landing on Malta. The pilots had to hope that they would be picked up by the ships. The eastern convoy was forced to turn back after a series of naval and air engagements, despite the British ships still having 20% of their ammunition left. It was considered insufficient to see them into Malta. The losses of the convoy were heavy. Among the British losses was the cruiser . Three destroyers and 11 merchant vessels were also sunk. Malta did send Bristol Beauforts to engage the Italian fleet and German U-boats attacking the convoy. They torpedoed and sank the heavy cruiser and damaged the battleship . Two freighters of the western convoy reached Malta and delivered supplies, making them the only ships out of a total of 17 to deliver their loads, 25,000\xa0tons of supplies. A further 16 Malta-based pilots were lost in the operations.\n', 'On the night of Operation Chastise, 16/17\xa0May 1943, Shannon was among a group of Lancasters led by Gibson in assaults on the Möhne and Eder Dams. After five of the aircraft had dropped their bouncing bombs on the Möhne, Shannon was preparing to make his attack on the dam when it gave way, so he carried on to the Eder with Gibson and three other Lancasters, captained by "Dinghy" Young, Henry Maudsley, and Les Knight. Detailed for the first bombing run at the Eder, Shannon took several attempts to familiarise himself with the area and line up his aircraft, so in the meantime Gibson ordered Maudsley to make his attack. Shannon went in next, delivering his bomb on target. Knight then dropped his bomb, and the dam broke.\n', '8 EBR troops at Sholoshahar were unaware of the attack on EBRC. Major Ziaur Rahman was away, making his way to port to unload ammunition from MV Swat around 11:45\xa0pm while Major Mir Shawkat Ali had been ordered to take a company to the port. When some of the EBRC survivors reached 8 EBR lines begging for help, Captain Oli Ahmad (Oli Ahmed) began recalling EBR troops to Sholoshahar and arrested all Pakistani soldiers and officers of the unit. After taking controle of 8 EBR Captain Oli Ahmad (Oli Ahmed) sent Captain Khalekuzzaman to find Zia and bring him back. Captain Khalek managed to find Maj. Zia and get his escort of Pakistani troops back to 8 EBR lines, where Zia managed to arrest his escort and order Bengali troops to revolt. Bengali officers were divided in their opinion, some wanted to take on the 20 Baluch at EBRC to save Bengali lives, but ultimately it was decided that such a move would be suicidal. 8 EBR left the city and took position across the Kalurghat bridge around 1:15\xa0am. Bengali troops killed all Pakistani prisoners including 8 EBR CO, Lt. Col. Janjua who was killed by his second in command Major Zia prior to moving out.\n', 'As the boarding progressed, a soldier heard Sharp and his chief officer, H. Grattidge, say that were on the ship, as a lighter came alongside and Sharp decide that it would be the last to deliver passengers. Sharp and Grattidge kept watch on the sky as aircraft fought above the Loire estuary and German bombers tried to hit about distant; at "Oronsay" was bombed and part of the bridge destroyed. Sharp was advised by the captain of "Havelock" to leave at once but for fear of U-boats, Sharp wanted a destroyer escort. No destroyer was forthcoming and Sharp decided to leave with "Oronsay"; "Lancastria" stayed at anchor rather than being made a moving target. At more German bombers appeared, while the RAF Hurricanes were at the far end of their patrol line and a bomber hit "Lancastria" with three or four bombs. The ship tilted to starboard, the bridge crew shouted for everyone to go to the port side and "Lancastria" came level again, then keeled over to port.\n', 'With the fate of the landing in the balance, Halsey ordered his carriers, under command of Rear-Admiral Frederick Sherman, to steam north through the night of 4–5 November to get within range of Rabaul for a daybreak raid on the base. Approaching behind the cover of a weather front, Sherman launched all 97 of his available aircraft against the target, leaving no aircraft behind for combat air patrol over his ships. The aircrews were ordered to damage as many warships as possible, rather than attempting to achieve a sinking. Aircraft from airfields on Barakoma and the recently captured Vella Lavella were sent out to sea to rendezvous with the carrier force to provide it with some measure of protection.\n', '"Kaiser" was to have taken part in a final fleet action days before the Armistice, an operation which envisioned the bulk of the High Seas Fleet sortieing from their base in Wilhelmshaven to engage the British Grand Fleet. In order to retain a better bargaining position for Germany, Admirals Hipper and Scheer intended to inflict as much damage as possible on the British navy, whatever the cost to the fleet. Consequently, on 29 October 1918, the order was given to depart from Wilhelmshaven to consolidate the fleet in the Jade roadstead, with the intention of departing the following morning. However, starting on the night of 29 October, sailors on mutinied. The unrest spread to other battleships, which forced Hipper and Scheer to cancel the operation.\n', 'Nelson in his letter of 9 March 1783, reports that he was in command of the squadron and the operation. Shortly after the squadron arrived at Turk\'s Island, "Tartar" left without explanation. Nelson states that he sent Dixon under a flag of truce to ask the French commander to surrender; the demand was refused. The British then landed 167 troops, under Dixon. Unexpectedly, a shore battery of three guns opened fire on the brigs. "Drake" master was wounded, as were some seven men aboard the "General Barrington". Dixon reported that seamen were manning the French guns and that the French troops had several field pieces. Nelson then decided to withdraw.\n']

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question of who led the soldiers in ending the raid on the Harper's Ferry arsenal, we first need to understand the context and key figures involved in this historical event. The raid, conducted by John Brown in October 1859, aimed to seize the federal arsenal at Harper's Ferry, Virginia (now West Virginia), with the intention of inciting a slave rebellion. 

1. **John Brown's Leadership**: John Brown was a prominent abolitionist who believed in armed resistance against slavery. His leadership during the raid was characterized by a fervent commitment to his cause, but it was also marked by strategic miscalculations. Understanding Brown's motivations and actions provides insight into the raid's objectives and its ultimate failure.

2. **Colonel Robert E. Lee's Role**: The raid was met with a swift response from federal forces. Colonel Robert E. Lee, who would later become a significant figure in the Confederate Army during the Civil War, was in command of the U.S. Marines dispatched to suppress the raid. His leadership was crucial in organizing the military response and ultimately ending the standoff at the arsenal. This highlights the importance of military leadership in crisis situations.

3. **Military Context**: The passages retrieved discuss various military operations and leadership roles, emphasizing the complexities of military command and the outcomes of raids. This context can be applied to the Harper's Ferry raid, illustrating how military strategy and leadership dynamics play a critical role in the success or failure of such operations.

4. **Historical Significance**: The Harper's Ferry raid is a pivotal event in American history, as it heightened tensions between the North and South and contributed to the onset of the Civil War. Understanding the broader historical context of the raid, including the societal attitudes toward slavery and the abolitionist movement, is essential for grasping its significance.

5. **Strategic Outcomes**: The raid ultimately failed, leading to Brown's capture and subsequent execution. This outcome serves as a case study in the challenges faced by revolutionary movements and the responses of established military forces.

### Conclusion

In summary, while John Brown led the initial raid on the Harper's Ferry arsenal, it was Colonel Robert E. Lee who led the soldiers in ending the raid. This understanding is enriched by the context of military leadership, the nature of raids, and the historical significance of the events surrounding the raid.

### Answer:
Colonel Robert E. Lee led the soldiers in ending the raid on the Harper's Ferry arsenal.

1. **John Brown's Raid**: John Brown, an abolitionist, led a raid on the Harper's Ferry arsenal in Virginia on October 16, 1859. His goal was to initiate an armed slave revolt by seizing weapons from the federal armory.

2. **Ending the Raid**: The raid was ultimately quelled by local militia and U.S. Marines, led by Colonel Robert E. Lee, who was then a lieutenant colonel. Lee's forces surrounded Brown and his men, leading to their capture.

3. **Significance**: The raid heightened tensions between the North and South and is often cited as a catalyst for the Civil War. Brown was tried and executed for treason, which further polarized public opinion on slavery.

While the retrieved passages provide insights into various military operations and leadership during the 20th century, they do not directly answer the question regarding the Harper's Ferry raid. The passages highlight the importance of command and strategy in military engagements, underscoring the role of leaders like Colonel Lee in critical moments of conflict.

In conclusion, the answer to the question is that Colonel Robert E. Lee led the soldiers in ending the raid on the Harper's Ferry arsenal, effectively quelling John Brown's attempt to incite a slave rebellion.

**Answer:**
Colonel Robert E. Lee led the soldiers in ending the raid on the Harper's Ferry arsenal.

logician.content:
You are a logician, to answer the following question:
who led the soldiers in ending the raid on the harper's ferry arsenal
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Elements of the 2nd Armored Division began to arrive in Algeria, French North Africa, in November 1942, as part of Operation Torch. Upon landing in Algiers, Harmon was delegated by General Dwight D. "Ike" Eisenhower, the Supreme Allied Commander in North Africa, to travel to the front to report on the deteriorating Allied situation in Tunisia and Algeria, and to assist where needed. His on-site reporting and interventions during the Kasserine Pass battles in February 1943 helped stabilize and reorganize the U.S. II Corps, which had been thrown into disorder after the initial German attack.
', 'In November 1941, these men carried out a raid on Beda Littoria, in Libya as part of Operation Flipper, with the purpose of capturing Erwin Rommel in his headquarters. The raid was a failure, Keyes was killed in a fire fight at Sidi Rafa and only a handful of the men managed to escape to British lines. For his part in the raid, Keyes received the Victoria Cross posthumously. After this raid the commando role changed and No. 11 Commando along with Layforce was disbanded, due mainly to a shortage of manpower.
', 'In April 1941, the Royal Navy and the RAF devised Operation Fuller, a plan for combined operations against the ships in Brest should they sortie. Vice-Admiral Bertram Ramsay of the Dover Command was to be responsible for operations to confront a German squadron sailing up the Channel with continuous co-ordinated attacks by Coastal Command, the Navy and RAF. The British coastal radar had a range of about and with the five standing air patrols, the planners expected a dash up the Channel easily to be discovered, even at night or in bad weather. As soon as the alarm was raised, the offensive provisions of Fuller would begin as a combined operation. The of the Dover and Ramsgate flotillas, with a Motor Gun Boat (MGB) escort, would make torpedo attacks from . The boats would be followed up by Swordfish torpedo-bombers with fighter escorts and Beaufort torpedo-bombers and the coastal guns at Dover would fire for as long as the ships were in range; Bomber Command would attack any ship damaged enough to have been slowed or brought to a stop.
', 'In June, the Royal Navy undertook Operation Harpoon and Operation Vigorous. The two convoys departed for Malta, the former from Gibraltar, the latter from Haifa and Port Said. The move was designed to split Axis naval forces attempting to intervene. Lloyd the AOC, wanted to give No. 601 Squadron over to convoy escort duty. Although he could afford this diversion, he could maintain a standing patrol of only four Spitfires over the convoy. If Axis aircraft attacked as they were withdrawing, they had to stay and fight. Bailing out if the pilots ran low on fuel was the only alternative to landing on Malta. The pilots had to hope that they would be picked up by the ships. The eastern convoy was forced to turn back after a series of naval and air engagements, despite the British ships still having 20% of their ammunition left. It was considered insufficient to see them into Malta. The losses of the convoy were heavy. Among the British losses was the cruiser . Three destroyers and 11 merchant vessels were also sunk. Malta did send Bristol Beauforts to engage the Italian fleet and German U-boats attacking the convoy. They torpedoed and sank the heavy cruiser and damaged the battleship . Two freighters of the western convoy reached Malta and delivered supplies, making them the only ships out of a total of 17 to deliver their loads, 25,000\xa0tons of supplies. A further 16 Malta-based pilots were lost in the operations.
', 'On the night of Operation Chastise, 16/17\xa0May 1943, Shannon was among a group of Lancasters led by Gibson in assaults on the Möhne and Eder Dams. After five of the aircraft had dropped their bouncing bombs on the Möhne, Shannon was preparing to make his attack on the dam when it gave way, so he carried on to the Eder with Gibson and three other Lancasters, captained by "Dinghy" Young, Henry Maudsley, and Les Knight. Detailed for the first bombing run at the Eder, Shannon took several attempts to familiarise himself with the area and line up his aircraft, so in the meantime Gibson ordered Maudsley to make his attack. Shannon went in next, delivering his bomb on target. Knight then dropped his bomb, and the dam broke.
', '8 EBR troops at Sholoshahar were unaware of the attack on EBRC. Major Ziaur Rahman was away, making his way to port to unload ammunition from MV Swat around 11:45\xa0pm while Major Mir Shawkat Ali had been ordered to take a company to the port. When some of the EBRC survivors reached 8 EBR lines begging for help, Captain Oli Ahmad (Oli Ahmed) began recalling EBR troops to Sholoshahar and arrested all Pakistani soldiers and officers of the unit. After taking controle of 8 EBR Captain Oli Ahmad (Oli Ahmed) sent Captain Khalekuzzaman to find Zia and bring him back. Captain Khalek managed to find Maj. Zia and get his escort of Pakistani troops back to 8 EBR lines, where Zia managed to arrest his escort and order Bengali troops to revolt. Bengali officers were divided in their opinion, some wanted to take on the 20 Baluch at EBRC to save Bengali lives, but ultimately it was decided that such a move would be suicidal. 8 EBR left the city and took position across the Kalurghat bridge around 1:15\xa0am. Bengali troops killed all Pakistani prisoners including 8 EBR CO, Lt. Col. Janjua who was killed by his second in command Major Zia prior to moving out.
', 'As the boarding progressed, a soldier heard Sharp and his chief officer, H. Grattidge, say that were on the ship, as a lighter came alongside and Sharp decide that it would be the last to deliver passengers. Sharp and Grattidge kept watch on the sky as aircraft fought above the Loire estuary and German bombers tried to hit about distant; at "Oronsay" was bombed and part of the bridge destroyed. Sharp was advised by the captain of "Havelock" to leave at once but for fear of U-boats, Sharp wanted a destroyer escort. No destroyer was forthcoming and Sharp decided to leave with "Oronsay"; "Lancastria" stayed at anchor rather than being made a moving target. At more German bombers appeared, while the RAF Hurricanes were at the far end of their patrol line and a bomber hit "Lancastria" with three or four bombs. The ship tilted to starboard, the bridge crew shouted for everyone to go to the port side and "Lancastria" came level again, then keeled over to port.
', 'With the fate of the landing in the balance, Halsey ordered his carriers, under command of Rear-Admiral Frederick Sherman, to steam north through the night of 4–5 November to get within range of Rabaul for a daybreak raid on the base. Approaching behind the cover of a weather front, Sherman launched all 97 of his available aircraft against the target, leaving no aircraft behind for combat air patrol over his ships. The aircrews were ordered to damage as many warships as possible, rather than attempting to achieve a sinking. Aircraft from airfields on Barakoma and the recently captured Vella Lavella were sent out to sea to rendezvous with the carrier force to provide it with some measure of protection.
', '"Kaiser" was to have taken part in a final fleet action days before the Armistice, an operation which envisioned the bulk of the High Seas Fleet sortieing from their base in Wilhelmshaven to engage the British Grand Fleet. In order to retain a better bargaining position for Germany, Admirals Hipper and Scheer intended to inflict as much damage as possible on the British navy, whatever the cost to the fleet. Consequently, on 29 October 1918, the order was given to depart from Wilhelmshaven to consolidate the fleet in the Jade roadstead, with the intention of departing the following morning. However, starting on the night of 29 October, sailors on mutinied. The unrest spread to other battleships, which forced Hipper and Scheer to cancel the operation.
', 'Nelson in his letter of 9 March 1783, reports that he was in command of the squadron and the operation. Shortly after the squadron arrived at Turk's Island, "Tartar" left without explanation. Nelson states that he sent Dixon under a flag of truce to ask the French commander to surrender; the demand was refused. The British then landed 167 troops, under Dixon. Unexpectedly, a shore battery of three guns opened fire on the brigs. "Drake" master was wounded, as were some seven men aboard the "General Barrington". Dixon reported that seamen were manning the French guns and that the French troops had several field pieces. Nelson then decided to withdraw.
']

question:
who led the soldiers in ending the raid on the harper's ferry arsenal
answer:

Therefore, while John Brown led the initial raid, it was Colonel Lee who led the soldiers in ending it.

Answer: Colonel Robert E. Lee led the soldiers in ending the raid on the Harper's Ferry arsenal.

To determine who led the soldiers in ending the raid on the Harper's Ferry arsenal, we must first establish the context of the event. The raid, which occurred in October 1859, was orchestrated by John Brown, an abolitionist who sought to incite an armed slave revolt by capturing the federal arsenal at Harper's Ferry, Virginia (now West Virginia). 

1. **Identification of Key Figures**: 
   - **John Brown**: He was the leader of the raid, aiming to arm enslaved people and initiate a rebellion against slavery.
   - **Colonel Robert E. Lee**: He was the commander of the U.S. Marines who were dispatched to suppress the raid.

2. **Causal Relationships**: 
   - The actions taken by John Brown led to the raid, which in turn prompted the federal government to respond by sending troops. This illustrates a clear cause-and-effect relationship: Brown's actions caused a military response.

3. **Military Response and Leadership**: 
   - The arrival of Colonel Lee and his Marines was a direct response to the chaos caused by Brown's raid. This highlights the role of military leadership in resolving conflicts and restoring order, showcasing how leadership decisions can significantly impact the outcome of events.

4. **Strategic Decision-Making**: 
   - The decision to send Marines to Harper's Ferry reflects strategic military planning, emphasizing the importance of timely and decisive action in military operations. This aspect enhances the understanding of how leaders assess situations and make decisions that lead to specific outcomes.

5. **Conclusion**: 
   - By synthesizing the information about the roles of John Brown and Colonel Robert E. Lee, we can conclude that while Brown initiated the raid, it was Colonel Lee who led the soldiers in ending it. This understanding reinforces the importance of recognizing both the initiators of actions and the responders in analyzing historical events.

### Answer:
Colonel Robert E. Lee led the soldiers in ending the raid on the Harper's Ferry arsenal.

For his part in the raid, Keyes received the Victoria Cross posthumously. After this raid the commando role changed and No. 11 Commando along with Layforce was disbanded, due mainly to a shortage of manpower.
In April 1941, the Royal Navy and the RAF devised Operation Fuller, a plan for combined operations against the ships in Brest should they sortie. Vice-Admiral Bertram Ramsay of the Dover Command was to be responsible for operations to confront a German squadron sailing up the Channel with continuous co-ordinated attacks by Coastal Command, the Navy and RAF. The British coastal radar had a range of about and with the five standing air patrols, the planners expected a dash up the Channel easily to be discovered, even at night or in bad weather. As soon as the alarm was raised, the offensive provisions of Fuller would begin as a combined operation. The of the Dover and Ramsgate flotillas, with a Motor Gun Boat (MGB) escort, would make torpedo attacks from . The boats would be followed up by Swordfish torpedo-bombers with fighter escorts and Beaufort torpedo-bombers and the coastal guns at Dover would fire for as long as the ships were in range; Bomber Command would attack any ship damaged enough to have been slowed or brought to a stop.
In June, the Royal Navy undertook Operation Harpoon and Operation Vigorous. The two convoys departed for Malta, the former from Gibraltar, the latter from Haifa and Port Said. The move was designed to split Axis naval forces attempting to intervene. Lloyd the AOC, wanted to give No. 601 Squadron over to convoy escort duty. Although he could afford this diversion, he could maintain a standing patrol of only four Spitfires over the convoy. If Axis aircraft attacked as they were withdrawing, they had to stay and fight. Bailing out if the pilots ran low on fuel was the only alternative to landing on Malta. The pilots had to hope that they would be picked up by the ships. The eastern convoy was forced to turn back after a series of naval and air engagements, despite the British ships still having 20% of their ammunition left. It was considered insufficient to see them into Malta. The losses of the convoy were heavy. Among the British losses was the cruiser . Three destroyers and 11 merchant vessels were also sunk. Malta did send Bristol Beauforts to engage the Italian fleet and German U-boats attacking the convoy. They torpedoed and sank the heavy cruiser and damaged the battleship . Two freighters of the western convoy reached Malta and delivered supplies, making them the only ships out of a total of 17 to deliver their loads, 25,000 tons of supplies. A further 16 Malta-based pilots were lost in the operations.
On the night of Operation Chastise, 16/17 May 1943, Shannon was among a group of Lancasters led by Gibson in assaults on the Möhne and Eder Dams. After five of the aircraft had dropped their bouncing bombs on the Möhne, Shannon was preparing to make his attack on the dam when it gave way, so he carried on to the Eder with Gibson and three other Lancasters, captained by "Dinghy" Young, Henry Maudsley, and Les Knight. Detailed for the first bombing run at the Eder, Shannon took several attempts to familiarise himself with the area and line up his aircraft, so in the meantime Gibson ordered Maudsley to make his attack. Shannon went in next, delivering his bomb on target. Knight then dropped his bomb, and the dam broke.
8 EBR troops at Sholoshahar were unaware of the attack on EBRC. Major Ziaur Rahman was away, making his way to port to unload ammunition from MV Swat around 11:45 pm while Major Mir Shawkat Ali had been ordered to take a company to the port. When some of the EBRC survivors reached 8 EBR lines begging for help, Captain Oli Ahmad (Oli Ahmed) began recalling EBR troops to Sholoshahar and arrested all Pakistani soldiers and officers of the unit. After taking controle of 8 EBR Captain Oli Ahmad (Oli Ahmed) sent Captain Khalekuzzaman to find Zia and bring him back. Captain Khalek managed to find Maj. Zia and get his escort of Pakistani troops back to 8 EBR lines, where Zia managed to arrest his escort and order Bengali troops to revolt. Bengali officers were divided in their opinion, some wanted to take on the 20 Baluch at EBRC to save Bengali lives, but ultimately it was decided that such a move would be suicidal. 8 EBR left the city and took position across the Kalurghat bridge around 1:15 am. Bengali troops killed all Pakistani prisoners including 8 EBR CO, Lt. Col. Janjua who was killed by his second in command Major Zia prior to moving out.
As the boarding progressed, a soldier heard Sharp and his chief officer, H. Grattidge, say that were on the ship, as a lighter came alongside and Sharp decide that it would be the last to deliver passengers. Sharp and Grattidge kept watch on the sky as aircraft fought above the Loire estuary and German bombers tried to hit about distant; at "Oronsay" was bombed and part of the bridge destroyed. Sharp was advised by the captain of "Havelock" to leave at once but for fear of U-boats, Sharp wanted a destroyer escort. No destroyer was forthcoming and Sharp decided to leave with "Oronsay"; "Lancastria" stayed at anchor rather than being made a moving target. At more German bombers appeared, while the RAF Hurricanes were at the far end of their patrol line and a bomber hit "Lancastria" with three or four bombs. The ship tilted to starboard, the bridge crew shouted for everyone to go to the port side and "Lancastria" came level again, then keeled over to port.
With the fate of the landing in the balance, Halsey ordered his carriers, under command of Rear-Admiral Frederick Sherman, to steam north through the night of 4–5 November to get within range of Rabaul for a daybreak raid on the base. Approaching behind the cover of a weather front, Sherman launched all 97 of his available aircraft against the target, leaving no aircraft behind for combat air patrol over his ships. The aircrews were ordered to damage as many warships as possible, rather than attempting to achieve a sinking. Aircraft from airfields on Barakoma and the recently captured Vella Lavella were sent out to sea to rendezvous with the carrier force to provide it with some measure of protection.
"Kaiser" was to have taken part in a final fleet action days before the Armistice, an operation which envisioned the bulk of the High Seas Fleet sortieing from their base in Wilhelmshaven to engage the British Grand Fleet. In order to retain a better bargaining position for Germany, Admirals Hipper and Scheer intended to inflict as much damage as possible on the British navy, whatever the cost to the fleet. Consequently, on 29 October 1918, the order was given to depart from Wilhelmshaven to consolidate the fleet in the Jade roadstead, with the intention of departing the following morning. However, starting on the night of 29 October, sailors on mutinied. The unrest spread to other battleships, which forced Hipper and Scheer to cancel the operation.
Nelson in his letter of 9 March 1783, reports that he was in command of the squadron and the operation. Shortly after the squadron arrived at Turk's Island, "Tartar" left without explanation. Nelson states that he sent Dixon under a flag of truce to ask the French commander to surrender; the demand was refused. The British then landed 167 troops, under Dixon. Unexpectedly, a shore battery of three guns opened fire on the brigs. "Drake" master was wounded, as were some seven men aboard the "General Barrington". Dixon reported that seamen were manning the French guns and that the French troops had several field pieces. Nelson then decided to withdraw.
